Because its IN THE CONSTRUCTOR, and my constructor does not take this 
as a parameter because other several classes use it and access it 
like this: ConfigManager.getInstance().  "ConfigManager" is a 
singleton because many classes in the system refer to it, it needs to 
keep some state, and when used I must guarantee that it already has 
this state.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Scott Stirling" <scottstirling@r...> 
wrote:
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: tobemligado <jasbell@c...>
> >
> > I have a singleton called "ConfigManager", where in its 
constructor
> > it reads in a bunch of files from a directory and creates 
objectsfrom
> > the files.  I am doing this because I want to say "ConfigManager 
is
> > not valid until these other objects have also been successfully
> > created".
> >
> > I want the "ConfigManager" to be able to read a directory full
> > of "bad files" in some test scenarios, a directory full of "good
> > files" in other test scenarios, and a directory full of "good and 
bad
> > files" in yet other test scenarios.  Ultimately, the program will
> > have to handle "good and bad files",
> >
> > My problem is that I need to "trick" the "ConfigManager" into 
using
> > the three directories in different test scenarios, but I dont 
want to
> > alter the fact that all objects are created in "ConfigManager's"
> > constructor.  Here is what is in the constructor for the
> > singleton "ConfigManager":
> > ----------------------------------------------------
> > String basePath = ServiceResources.CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY;
> > setBaseDirectory(basePath);
> > loadAllFilesFound(getBaseDirectory());
> > loadConfigFilesFound(getAllFilesFoundList());
> > ArrayList configList = createConfigurations(getConfigFilesFound
());
> > TriggerManager tm = TriggerManager.getInstance();
> > ArrayList triggerList = tm.createTriggers(configList);
> > tm.registerTriggers(triggerList);
> > ----------------------------------------------------
> >
> > How can I switch the CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY value for testing when 
its
> > in the constructor?
> 
> Why can't you just change the value of
> ServiceResources.CONFIG_FILE_DIRECTORY before you call 
ConfigManager's
> constructor?
> 
> Scott Stirling
